Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Medium: Collaborative Research: Architecting Performance Sensitive Applications for the Cloud

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cloud computing offers IT organizations the ability to create
geo-distributed, and highly scalable applications while providing
attractive cost-saving advantages. Yet, architecting, configuring, and
adapting cloud applications (latency-sensitive web applications and
bulk data processing applications) to meet their stringent performance
requirements is a challenge given the rich set of configuration
options, shared multi-tenant nature of cloud platforms, and dynamics
resulting from activities such as planned maintenance.

This project is developing novel methodologies, algorithms, and
systems that can enable application architects to (1) judiciously
architect applications across multiple cloud data-centers while
considering application performance requirements, cost saving
objectives, and cloud pricing schemes guided by performance and cost
models of cloud components; (2) automatically learn effective
application configurations and configuration-to-performance prediction
models through statistical machine learning techniques; and (3) create
applications that can adapt to ongoing dynamics in cloud environments
through transaction reassignment over shorter time-scales, and
application migration over longer time-scales.

The impact of this research is multi-fold: (1) Enable IT organizations
to significantly reduce costs by optimally moving their operations to
the cloud; (2) create benchmarks based on operationally deployed
applications and collecting workload traces which will be made
available to the research community; (3) make developed algorithms and
systems widely available as open source software; (4) inform the
design of a nation-wide health-care cloud in Thailand; (4) introduce
cloud computing related topics in the undergraduate and graduate
curriculum; and (6) train multiple Ph.D., M.S., and undergraduate
students, with explicit effort to recruit and train students from
under-represented minority groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cloud computing offers the ability to create geo-distributed, and highly scalable applications while providing attractive cost-saving advantages. Yet, architecting, configuring, and adapting interactive cloud applications to meet their stringent latency requirements is a challenge given the rich set of configuration options, shared multi-tenant nature of cloud platforms, and dynamics resulting from activities such as planned maintenance. A complementary challenge is latency that users experience when downloading web-pages from a cloud application. The project made contributions in several areas to tackle these latency challenges.

First, in collaboration with Rice University, the project conducted an extensive measurement study on Amazon EC2 over multiple application. The measurement study revealed that cloud provider policy impacts the relative performance of different configurations, and policy decisions impact configuration performance in surprising ways. These results inspired a continuous price-performance benchmarking of the cloud made available to the industry by Burstorm Inc.

Second, the project developed frameworks that can automatically determine how best to customize the replication configuration of geo-distributed datastores to meet desired application objectives. The project developed models that optimize percentiles of response time under normal operation and under a data-center (DC) failure, while considering factors like the geographic spread of users, DC locations, consistency requirements and inter-DC communication costs. An evaluation of our models using real-world traces ofTwitter, Wikipedia and Gowalla on a Cassandra cluster deployed in Amazon EC2 confirmed the importance and effectiveness of our models, and highlighted the benefits of customizing replication in cloud datastores.

Third, the project developed Parcel, a system to reduce the latencies of web pages over cellular networks by 2X. Parcel's approach involved a cloud-based solution that fetched objects in a web-page over a fast network, and proactively pushed the objects to the client. The project also developed novel techniques to improve end-user experience with Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) as popular web sites turn to them for full site delivery. In particular, the paper showed the benefits of page-structure-aware strategies for placing objects in CDN cache hierarchies, and demonstrated that placing objects in a web page that have the largest impact on page latency should be served out of the closest or fastest caches in the hierarchy. The project showed that latency reductions of over 100 ms can be obtained for 30% of the popular pages, with even larger reductions for the less popular pages.

The project has involved 5 Ph.D students, and supported research that formed the basis of the Ph.D dissertations of 3 of the students. The students after graduation have gone on to industry positions at Microsoft Azure, AT&T Research, and a post-doctoral position at Carnegie Mellon University. The project also involved 4 undergraduate students, and a Visiting Researcher from Spain. The project led to 2 journal publications, 6 conference publications, and an invited paper in prestigious forums such as the IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communication, the IEEE Transactions on Cloud Computing, ACM CoNext, Usenix NSDI, IEEE Infocom, IEEE/IFIP DSN, ACM Sigmetrics, and Usenix NSDI. Results from the project were also disseminated to the industry through talks at places including VMWare, Facebook, Twitter, NetApp and Google.
